title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Networks
text: begin introducing centrality statistics defining types influence measure. igraph package many useful functions. network \(G = (V, E)\) consists two sets, set nodes (also called vertices), \(V\), set edges, \(E\). node set, \(V = \{v_i: = 1, ..., n\}\), consists \(n\) nodes network , without loss generality, labeled 1, 2, …, \(n\). edge set \(E = \{(,j) : e_{,j} = 1, ,j = 1,...,n\}\) consists edges \(e_{,j}=1\) exists connection nodes \(v_i\) \(v_j\), 0 otherwise. often mathematically convenient arrange edges matrix. Let \(\boldsymbol{}\) graph \(G\), \(A_{,j} = e_{,j}\) \((,j)^{\text{th}}\) entry \(\boldsymbol{}\). Throughout section, use karate network example. network represents members university karate club broke two factors, one led John (circles), Mr. Hi (squares). nodes members karate club edge present two nodes two respective actors participated common activities together.
code: data("karate") l <- layout_nicely(karate) V(karate)$x <- l[,1] V(karate)$y <- l[,2]  net <- intergraph::asNetwork(karate)  net %v% "shape" <- ifelse(V(karate)$Faction == 1, "circle", "triangle") delete.vertex.attribute(net, "color")  ggnet2(net,        label = TRUE,         node.shape = "shape",        mode = c("x", "y"),        node.label = "label") +   scale_shape(name = "Faction", labels = c("Mr. Hi", "John A."))

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Networks
text: One way measure influence number connections actor . actor many connections consider influential due “popularity” among actors, whereas actor relatively connections consider “unpopular”. Degree centrality measures type influence. , \(d_i\), node number edges connected defined multiple statistics,\[\begin{equation}     \gamma_i^{\text{deg}} = \sum_{j} e_{,j} = \sum_{j} A_{,j} = \sum_{} A_{,j}. \end{equation}\] Popular actors large degree connected many actors, unpopular actors small degree connected actors. maximum degree \(n-1\) occurs node connected nodes. minimum degree \(0\) occurs node connected node (.e. isolated). reason, degree often normalized constant \(n-1\). \[\begin{equation}     \gamma_i^{\text{deg}} = \frac{1}{n-1}\sum_{j} e_{,j} = \frac{1}{n-1}\sum_{j} A_{,j} = \frac{1}{n-1}\sum_{} A_{,j}. \end{equation}\] Let’s look degree karate network. plot light blue nodes low degree dark blue nodes high degree. Mr. Hi, John ., Node 33 highest degree values thus “popular”.
code: deg <- igraph::degree(karate) net %v% "deg.cols" <- colour_values(deg, palette = "blues") ggnet2(net,        label = TRUE,         node.shape = "shape",        mode = c("x", "y"),        node.label = "label",        node.color = "deg.cols") +   scale_shape(name = "Faction", labels = c("Mr. Hi", "John A."))

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Networks
text: Degree centrality measures influence number connections node . However, may case nodes equally important connected . example, measuring node’s popularity, addition number connections node , may also want consider popular nodes (Lü et al. 2016). relational structure captured eigenvector centrality (Bonacich 1972). Nodes high eigenvector centrality influential closely connected nodes also influential. Eigenvector centrality calculated \[\begin{equation}\label{eqn:eigen}     \gamma_i^{\text{ev}} = \frac{1}{\lambda} \sum_{j=1}^n A_{,j}\gamma_j^{\text{ev}}. \end{equation}\] karate network, Node 3 large eigenvector centrality connected Mr. Hi Actor 33, also large eigenvector centralities.
code: ev <- igraph::eigen_centrality(karate)$vector net %v% "ev.cols" <- colour_values(ev, palette = "blues") ggnet2(net,        label = TRUE,         node.shape = "shape",        mode = c("x", "y"),        node.label = "label",        node.color = "ev.cols") +   scale_shape(name = "Faction", labels = c("Mr. Hi", "John A.")) # Connections of Node 3 igraph::neighborhood(karate, order = 1, nodes = 3) #> [[1]] #> + 11/34 vertices, named, from 4b458a1: #>  [1] Actor 3  Mr Hi    Actor 2  Actor 4  Actor 8  Actor 9  Actor 10 Actor 14 #>  [9] Actor 28 Actor 29 Actor 33

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Networks
text: Closeness centrality distance-based metric captures central node network (bavelas-1950?). closeness node \(\) reciprocal average distance along shortest paths node \(\) \(n-1\) nodes network. Close'' nodes large closeness values short average distance nodes network influential due ability receive disseminate information quickly directly every node network.Far’’ nodes small closeness values long average distance nodes. Mr. Hi, John ., Node 33 large closeness centralities large degree values. Nodes large degree values tend large closeness centralities due highly connected positions network. Additionally, Node 20 high closeness centrality connected two highly connected nodes (Mr. Hi John .).
code: close <- igraph::closeness(karate) net %v% "close.cols" <- colour_values(close, palette = "blues") ggnet2(net,        label = TRUE,         node.shape = "shape",        mode = c("x", "y"),        node.label = "label",        node.color = "close.cols") +   scale_shape(name = "Faction", labels = c("Mr. Hi", "John A.")) igraph::neighborhood(karate, order = 1, nodes = 20) #> [[1]] #> + 4/34 vertices, named, from 4b458a1: #> [1] Actor 20 Mr Hi    Actor 2  John A

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Networks
text: described vignette("jab-regression"), JaB algorithm regression identifies influential points. algorithm direct analogy network data. Using centrality statistics, can detect influential nodes networks follows: node network \(G=(V,E)\), test hypotheses \(H_0\): node \(\) influential network, versus \(H_1\): node \(\) influential network. Specify centrality statistic, \(\gamma\), quantifies type influence want measure. Define \(q\[0, 1]\) upper quantile cut value \(B\) number bootstrap samples. JaB algorithm three steps: Step 1 (centrality step): \(v_i \V\), calculate \(\gamma_i\). Step 2 (bootstrapping step): Generate bootstrap samples \(G^{*b}=(V^{*b}, E^{*b})\) \(b=1,...,B\). bootstrap sample, calculate \(\{\gamma_j^{*b} : j=1,...,n\}\). Step 3 (jackknife-step): \(=1,...,n\); Calculate \(S_i^{*b} = \boldsymbol{1}(v_i \V^{*b})\) \(b=1,...,B\) construct \(\mathcal{B}_{-} = {G^{*b}: S_i^{*b} = 0)\) set bootstrap sample networks contain node \(\). Let \(\Gamma\_{-} = \{\gamma_j^{*b} : G^{*b} \\mathcal{B}_{-}, j=1,...,n\}\) set centrality statistics calculated bootstrap sample networks contain node \(\). Calculate cutoff value, \(q_{-}\), \(q^{\text{th}}\) quantile \(\Gamma_{-}\). \(\gamma_i > q_{-}\), reject Hypothesis null hypothesis conclude data node \(\) influential. Additionally, use bootstrap samples generated Step 2 JaB algorithm construct bootstrap standard errors confidence intervals. Let \(\mathcal{B}_i = \{G^{*b} : S_i^{*b} = 1\}\) set bootstrap networks include \(v_i\) \(\Gamma_i = \{\gamma_j : v_j^{*b} = v_i , v_j^{*b} \V^{*b}\}\) set centrality statistics corresponding nodes sampled \(v_i\). bootstrap standard error \(\gamma_i\) \[\sigma_i^* = \sqrt{(|\Gamma_i |-1)^{-1} \sum_{\gamma_j \\Gamma_i} (\gamma_j - \Bar{\gamma}_i)^2}\] \(\Bar{\gamma}_i = |\Gamma_i|^{-1}\sum_{\gamma_j \\Gamma_i} \gamma_j\). Using \(\sigma_i^{ *}\), bootstrap confidence intervals constructed traditional way. example, 95% bootstrap confidence interval \(\gamma_i\) \((\gamma_i - 1.96\sigma_i^{ *} , \gamma_i + 1.96\sigma_i^{ *})\). many centrality statistics \(\gamma_i\) must non-negative value. case \(\gamma_i\) must non-negative \(\gamma_i - 1.96\sigma_i^{ *}<0\), set 95% bootstrap confidence interval \((0, \gamma_i + 1.96\sigma_i^{ *})\). construction \(\mathcal{B}_i \cap \mathcal{B}_{-} = \emptyset\). bootstrap samples \(\mathcal{B}_i\) used bootstrap standard errors bootstrap samples \(\mathcal{B}_{-}\) used hypothesis test node \(v_i\)’s influence.

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Networks
code: result <- karate.result <- jab_network(   network = karate,   central.func.name = "degree",   central.package.name = "igraph",   central.func.args = list(normalized = TRUE),   bootstrap.func.name = "bootstrap_snowboot" ,   bootstrap.package.name = "JaB" ,   bootstrap.func.args = list( num.seed = 1, num.wave = 2 ),   B = 1000,   quant = 0.90,   nodes = NULL,   return.boot.samples = FALSE)  kable(karate.result) %>%    kable_styling()

what: Detecting Outliers and Influential Points in Linear Regression
title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression
text: vignette, use linear regression model \(n\) observations \(p\) predictors: \[\boldsymbol{Y} = \boldsymbol{X}\beta + \boldsymbol{\epsilon}\] \(\boldsymbol{Y} \\mathbb{R}^{n \times 1}\) vector responses, \(\boldsymbol{X} \\mathbb{R}^{n\times p}\) full rank design matrix \(p\) predictors, \(\beta \\mathbb{R}^{p\times 1}\) vector parameters, \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\\mathbb{R}^{n\times 1}\) vector Normal, ..d. errors. define several useful values Belsley, Kuh, Welsch (2005) Beyaztas Alin (2013), next define influence statistics traditional cut values Belsley, Kuh, Welsch (2005) Beyaztas Alin (2013), \[ \begin{align*} LD_i &= 2[\ell(\hat{\beta}) - \ell(\hat{\beta}_{()}) ]\\ & = n \log\left[\left(\frac{n}{n-1}\right)\left( \frac{n-p-1}{t_i^{*2} + n -p - 1}\right)\right] \\ & \;\;\;\;+ \frac{t_i^{*2}(n-1)}{(1-h_{ii})(n-p-1)}-1 \end{align*} \] \(\ell\) log-likelihood function.

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression
text: goal determine \(^{\text{th}}\) observation influential given influence statistic. JaB algorithm generates “null distribution” influence statistics assumption observation consideration influential. idea original influence statistic observation \(\) extreme value “null distribution”, flagged influential. One way generating distribution considering bootstrap samples observation \(\) present. observation \(\) bootstrap sample, influential model estimated bootstrap sample. JaB algorithm detecting influential observations linear regression proposed Martin Roberts (2010) follows: Step 1: Let \(\gamma\) diagnostic statistic interest. Fit model \(M\) calculate \(\gamma_i\) \(=1,…,n\). Step 2: Construct \(B\) bootstrap samples, replacement, original data set. Step 3: \(= 1,…,n\) , Let \(B_{()}\) set bootstrap samples contain data point \(\). sample \(B_{()}\), fit regression model calculate \(n\) values \(\gamma_{, (b)}\). Aggregate one vector \(\Gamma_i\) . Calculate suitable quantiles \(\Gamma_i\) (say 0.025 0.975). \(\gamma_i\) outside range, flag point \(\) influential.

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression
text: Let’s look example JaB algorithm works simple linear regression originally included Martin Roberts (2010). base model \[ Y = 1 + 2X + \epsilon \] \(p=2\) \(n=20\) . generate \(X_i \overset{iid}{\sim} \text{N}(2,1)\) \(\epsilon_i \overset{iid}{\sim} N(0, 0.5625)\) estimate linear regression model. plot 20 points fitted line blue.  Next, deliberately add influential point (5, 2) check JaB algorithm can detect . point added red red line fitted line \(n=21\) linear model.  fit regression model 21 points use jab_lm function run JaB algorithm DFFITS, 3100 bootstrap sample, quantile cutoffs 0.025 0.975. Finally, look points JaB algorithm flagged influential. jab_lm function outputs table row index observation, lower upper cutoff values, original statistic, indicator observation flagged influential. can see output inserted point flagged original DFFITS value -7.7 lower cutoff -0.68. can also look average cutoff values original 20 points see different cutoff value 21\(^{\text{st}}\) point. averages quite different cutoff 21\(^{\text{st}}\) point, suggesting point 21 influential. can also directly visualize cutoff values JaB algorithm point. plot , point data set plot original DFFITS value line lower upper cutoff values. point within line, flagged influential (colored red), point outside line flagged influential (colored blue). can see plot point 21 one flagged influential. can also see cutoff values point 21 quite different first 20 points.
code: set.seed(540) n <- 20 p <- 2  #Y = 1 + 2X + e beta_0 <- 1 beta_1 <- 2  X <- rnorm(n, 2, 1) e_norm <- rnorm(n, 0, sd = 0.5625^(1/2)) Y <- beta_0 + beta_1*X + e_norm  dat_orig <- data.frame(X, Y)  plot.orig <-    ggplot() +   geom_point(data = dat_orig, aes(x=X,y=Y), color = "blue") +   geom_smooth(data = dat_orig, aes(x=X,y=Y), method='lm', formula= y~x, se = F) plot.orig +   theme_minimal() #add Influential Point n <- n+1 Y1 <- c(Y, 2) X <- c(X, 5)  dat_new <-  data.frame(X,Y1)  plot.orig +   geom_point(data = data.frame(x=5, y=2), aes(x=x,y=y), color = "red")  +   geom_smooth(data = dat_new, aes(x=X,y=Y1), method='lm', formula= y~x, se = F, color = "red") +   theme_minimal()+   ylab("Y") mod1 <- lm(Y1 ~ X, data = dat_new) result1 <- jab_lm(mod1,                    stat = "dffits",                    quant.lower = 0.025,                    quant.upper = 0.975,                   B=3100) result1[result1$influential, ]  #>    row.ID      lower     upper      orig influential #> 21     21 -0.6799764 0.7851924 -7.704647        TRUE result1 %>%    filter(row.ID != 21) %>%    summarise(lower.avg = mean(lower),             upper.avg = mean(upper),             mean.dffits = mean(orig))  #>   lower.avg upper.avg mean.dffits #> 1 -1.637976 0.6117787  0.04061036 result1 %>%    ggplot() +   geom_segment(aes(x = row.ID, y = lower, yend = upper), color = "darkgray") +   geom_point(aes(x = row.ID, y = orig, color = influential)) +   ggtitle("Result of JaB Algorithm") +   xlab("Observation ID") +   ylab("DFFITS") +   theme_minimal()+   scale_color_discrete(name = "Flagged as Influential")

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression
text: next look example Life Cycle Savings data datasets package. data set contains 1960 1970 average personal savings, percent population 15, percent population 75, per-capita disposal income percentage growth rage disposable income 50 countries. model average personal savings function four covariates. investigate countries flagged influential studentized residuals, DFFITS, likelihood distance. studentized residuals built functions stats package, likelihood distance .
code: data("LifeCycleSavings", package = "datasets") mod2 <- lm(sr ~ ., data = LifeCycleSavings)

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression
text: Let’s first consider studentized residuals quantile cutoffs 0.025 0.975. traditional cutoff studentized residuals \(\pm t_{0.975, n-p-1} = \pm 2.10\) flags Chile Zambia. JaB algorithm also flags Chile Zambia influential. can also visualize JaB results plotting lower upper quantile values. plot includes six countries, two influential studentized residuals (Chile Zambia), four (Japan, Libya, Spain, Italy). plot can see Chile flagged influential lower cutoff value Zambia flagged upper cutoff value.
code: # JaB with studentized residuals result2 <- jab_lm(mod2,                   stat = "rstudent",                   quant.lower = 0.025,                   quant.upper = 0.975,                   B = 3100)  result2 %>%    mutate(traditional.cuttoff = qt(0.975, df = n-p-1)) %>%    mutate(traditioanl.flag = abs(orig) > traditional.cuttoff) %>%    rowwise() %>%    mutate(country = rownames(LifeCycleSavings)[row.ID]) %>%    select(country, orig,traditioanl.flag,  lower, upper, influential, ) %>%    filter(traditioanl.flag | influential) %>%    mutate(across(c(lower, upper, orig), function(x)round(x,2))) %>%    kable(col.names = c("Country", "Studentized Residual", "Traditional Flag", "Lower Cutoff", "Upper Cutoff", "JaB Flag")) %>%    kable_styling() %>%    add_header_above(c(" " = 3, "JaB Results" = 3)) result2 %>%    rowwise() %>%    mutate(country = rownames(LifeCycleSavings)[row.ID]) %>%   filter(country %in% c("Chile", "Zambia", "Japan", "Libya", "Spain", "Italy")) %>%    ggplot() +   geom_segment(aes(x = country, y = lower, yend = upper), color = "darkgray") +   geom_point(aes(x = country, y = orig, color = influential)) +   ggtitle("Result of JaB Algorithm") +   xlab("Country") +   ylab("Studentized Residuals") +   theme_minimal()+   scale_color_discrete(name = "Flagged as Influential")

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression
text: Next, consider JaB DFFITS quantile cutoffs 0.025 0.975. traditional cutoff value DFFITS \(\pm 2\sqrt{p/n} = \pm 2\sqrt{5/50} = 0.63\) flags Japan, Zambia, Libya. JaB DFFITS also flags three countries. visualize JaB results six countries previously mentioned. plot can see Libya flagged ’s lower cutoff value Japan Zambia flagged respective cutoff values. Unlike results JaB studentized residuals, Chile flagged influential lower upper cutoff values.
code: result3 <- jab_lm(mod2,                   stat = "dffits",                   quant.lower = 0.025,                   quant.upper = 0.975,                   B = 3100) result3 %>%    mutate(traditional.cuttoff = 2 * sqrt(5/50)) %>%    mutate(traditioanl.flag = abs(orig) > traditional.cuttoff) %>%    rowwise() %>%    mutate(country = rownames(LifeCycleSavings)[row.ID]) %>%    select(country, orig,traditioanl.flag,  lower, upper, influential, ) %>%    filter(traditioanl.flag | influential) %>%    mutate(across(c(lower, upper, orig), function(x)round(x,2))) %>%    kable(col.names = c("Country", "DFFITS", "Traditional Flag", "Lower Cutoff", "Upper Cutoff", "JaB Flag")) %>%    kable_styling() %>%    add_header_above(c(" " = 3, "JaB Results" = 3)) result3 %>%    rowwise() %>%    mutate(country = rownames(LifeCycleSavings)[row.ID]) %>%   filter(country %in% c("Chile", "Zambia", "Japan", "Libya", "Spain", "Italy")) %>%    ggplot() +   geom_segment(aes(x = country, y = lower, yend = upper), color = "darkgray") +   geom_point(aes(x = country, y = orig, color = influential)) +   ggtitle("Result of JaB Algorithm") +   xlab("Country") +   ylab("DFFITS") +   theme_minimal()+   scale_color_discrete(name = "Flagged as Influential")

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression
text: Lastly, use JaB likelihood distance. likelihood distance always positive, consider lower cutoff (set quant.lower=0), consider upper cutoff. example consider upper 0.03 quantile (set quant.upper =0.97). Additionally, likelihood distance built-function stats package, can define . traditional cutoff value likelihood distance \(\chi^2_{0.97, p} = 7.01\) flag countries influential. JaB algorithm flags Japan, Zambia, Libya. histogram likelihood distances , can see none values near traditional cutoff 12.83. suggests likelihood distance may “conservative” influence statistic data set using JaB algorithm likelihood distance may appropriate.  Looking results JaB algorithm likelihood distance six counties, can see likelihood distance values Zambia Libya well respective cutoff values suggesting definitely influential, whereas Japan’s value slight cutoff suggesting “barley” influential.
code: infl_like <- function(mod){      # input lm model object   # output n statistics, one for each observation    n <- length(mod$fitted.values)   p <- length(mod$coefficients)    ti <- rstudent(mod)   h <- hatvalues(mod)    p1 <- log( (n/(n-1)) * ((n-p-1) / (ti^2 +n-p-1)) )   p2 <- ti^2 * (n-1) / (1-h) / (n-p-1)    return(n*p1 + p2 - 1) }  ## JaB with Likelihood Distance result4 <- jab_lm(mod2,                   stat = "infl_like",                   quant.lower = 0,                   quant.upper = 0.97,                   B = 3100) result4 %>%    mutate(traditional.cuttoff = qchisq(0.97, df = p)) %>%    mutate(traditioanl.flag = abs(orig) > traditional.cuttoff) %>%    rowwise() %>%    mutate(country = rownames(LifeCycleSavings)[row.ID]) %>%    select(country, orig,traditioanl.flag,  lower, upper, influential, ) %>%    filter(traditioanl.flag | influential) %>%    mutate(across(c(lower, upper, orig), function(x)round(x,2))) %>%    kable(col.names = c("Country", "Likelihood Distance", "Traditional Flag", "Lower Cutoff", "Upper Cutoff", "JaB Flag")) %>%    kable_styling() %>%    add_header_above(c(" " = 3, "JaB Results" = 3)) hist(result4$orig, breaks = 12, freq = T,      main = "Histogram of Likelihood Distance",      xlab = "Likelihood Disance",       ylab = "Frequency") result4 %>%    rowwise() %>%    mutate(country = rownames(LifeCycleSavings)[row.ID]) %>%   filter(country %in% c("Chile", "Zambia", "Japan", "Libya", "Spain", "Italy")) %>%    ggplot() +   geom_segment(aes(x = country, y = lower, yend = upper), color = "darkgray") +   geom_point(aes(x = country, y = orig, color = influential)) +   ggtitle("Result of JaB Algorithm") +   xlab("Country") +   ylab("Lieklihood Distance") +   theme_minimal()+   scale_color_discrete(name = "Flagged as Influential")

title: Mallows Distance Equivalence Test
text:
Say \(X_i \overset{iid}{\sim} F\) \(= 1, ..., n\) \(Y_j \overset{iid}{\sim} G\) \(j = 1, ..., m\) \(F\) \(G\) continuous distribution functions. Let \(\hat{F}_n(x) =  rac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^n  oldsymbol{1}\{X_i \leq x\}\) denote empirical cumulative distribution function (ECDF) \(X\), \(\hat{F}^{-1}_n(t) = \inf\{x : F_n(x) \geq t\}\) denote quantile function. Define \(\hat{G}_m(y)\) \(\hat{G}^{-1}_m(t)\) similarly \(Y\). \(p^{	ext{th}}\) Mallow’s distance (Mallows 1972) (also Wasserstein distance case CDFs): \[ egin{equation}     \Psi_p (F, G) = \left[ \int_0^1 | F^{-1}(u) - G^{-1}(u) | ^p du ight]^{1/p}. \end{equation}\] Trimmed \(p^{th}\) Mallows distance trimming parameter \(\alpha \[0, 1/2)\) : \[ egin{equation}     \Psi_{\alpha, p}(F, G) =   rac{1}{1-2\alpha} \left[ \int_{\alpha}^{1-\alpha} | F^{-1}(u) - G^{-1}(u) | ^p du ight]^{1/p}. \end{equation}\] Munk Czado (1998) conduct equivalence test suitable \(0<\Delta_0\mathbb{R}\): \[ egin{equation}     H_0: \Psi_{\alpha, 2}(F, G) \geq \Delta_0 \quad 	ext{versus} \quad H_A:  \Psi_{\alpha, 2}(F, G) < \Delta_0 \end{equation}\] Assume \(\{\alpha_{n \wedge m}\}_{n,m \mathbb{N}}\) sequence trimming bounds satisfying regularity conditions Munk Czado (1998). Let \(n\wedge m \infty\) \(n / (n + m) \lambda \(0,1)\). \(\Psi_{\alpha, 2}(F,G) < \infty\) , \[ egin{equation}     \left( rac{nm}{n+m}ight)^{1/2} \Big[\Psi^2_{\alpha_{n \wedge m}, 2}(\hat{F}_n, \hat{G}_n) -  \Psi^2_{\alpha, 2}(F, G) \Big] \overset{d}{\} N(0, \sigma^2_{\alpha}(F, G)) \end{equation}\] \[ egin{align}     \sigma^2_{\alpha}(F, G) &=  rac{4}{(1-2\alpha)^4} \left[ \lambda \sigma^2_{\alpha}(F|G)+ (1-\lambda)\sigma^2_{\alpha}(G|F) ight]  \     \sigma^2_{\alpha}(F|G) &= T_{\alpha}^{**}(F, G) - [T_{\alpha}^{*}(F,G)]^2  \label{eqn:Sigma2FG}\     T_{\alpha}^{**}(F, G) &=   \int_0^{1-\alpha} \Bigg[ \int_{\alpha \vee s}^{1-\alpha} h_{F|G}(t) dt \Bigg]^2 ds  \label{eqn:Sigma2T2}\     T_{\alpha}^{*}(F, G) &=   \int_0^{1-\alpha} \Bigg[ \int_{\alpha \vee s}^{1-\alpha} h_{F|G}(t) dt \Bigg] ds \label{eqn:Sigma2T1} \     h_{F|G}(t) &=  rac{F^{-1}(t) - G^{-1}(t) }{ f \circ F^{-1}(t)}. \end{align}\] \(\sigma^2_{\alpha}(G|F)\) \(\sigma^2_{\alpha}(F|G)\) roles \(F\) \(G\) reversed. See Munk Czado (1998) full list regularity conditions. , consistent level \(\alpha^*\) test hypothesis rejects \(H_0\) , \[ egin{equation}     \left( rac{nm}{n+m}ight)^{1/2}  rac{\Psi^2_{\alpha_{n \wedge m}, 2}(\hat{F}_n, \hat{G}_n) - \Delta_0^2}{\hat{\sigma}_{\alpha}(F, G)} \leq q_{\alpha^*} \end{equation}\] \(q_{\alpha^*}\) \(\alpha^*\) quantile standard normal distribution \(\hat{\sigma}_{\alpha}\) consistent estimator \(\sigma_{\alpha}\). Let \(x_{()}\) \(^{	ext{th}}\) order statistic sample \(X\). Define \(y_{()}\) similarly. case \(n=m\), \(\hat{\sigma}_{\alpha}\) calculated using: \[ egin{align}     T_{\alpha}^{*}(\hat{F}_n, \hat{G}_n) &=  \alpha \left[  rac{1}{2} \left( x_{(n-)}^2 - x_{()}^2 ight) - \sum_{=}^{n--1}  y_{()} (x_{(+1)} - x_{()}) ight] 
onumber\     &\quad +  rac{1 - 2\alpha}{2}x_{(n-)}^2 -  rac{1}{2n} \sum_{=+1}^{n-}x_{()}^2   -   rac{1}{n}\sum_{j=+1}^{n-}\sum_{=j}^{n--1}  y_{()} (x_{(+1)} - x_{()}) \      T_{\alpha}^{**}(\hat{F}, \hat{G}) &= \alpha \left[  rac{1}{2} \left( x_{(n-)}^2 - x_{()}^2 ight) - \sum_{=}^{n--1}  y_{()} (x_{(+1)} - x_{()}) ight]^2 
onumber \      & \quad + rac{1}{4n}\sum_{=+1}^{n-} (x_{(n-)}^2 - x_{()}^2)^2 -  rac{1}{n}\sum_{j=+1}^{n--1} \left[ \left(x_{(n-)} ^2 - x_{()}^2 ight)   \sum_{=j}^{n--1}  y_{()} (x_{(+1)} - x_{()})  ight] 
onumber \      &\quad +  rac{1}{n} \sum_{j=+1}^{n--1}  \sum_{=j}^{n--1}  y_{()} (x_{(+1)} - x_{()})   \end{align}\] \(\) integer \(\alpha = /n\). Note case \(\sigma_{\alpha}(F,G) = 0\) degenerate limit: \[ egin{equation}     \left( rac{nm}{n+m}ight)^{1/2} \Big[\Psi^2_{\alpha_{n \wedge m}, 2}(\hat{F}_n, \hat{G}_n) -  \Psi^2_{\alpha, 2}(F, G) \Big] \overset{p}{\} 0 \end{equation}\] authors find even case, test remains consistent sequence hypothesis \(H_{n,m} :\Psi_{\alpha, 2}(F, G)  \geq \Delta_{0,n,m}\), long \(\Delta_0^{-1} = o(\sqrt{n \vee m})\). implies can assess similarly \(F\) \(G\) long test approaches \(\Psi_{\alpha, 2}(F, G)	o0\) slower rate \(1/\sqrt{n}\). can particularly useful large sample case, may impractical small sample sizes.

title: Mallows Distance Equivalence Test
text: remainder vignette, consider case \(n=m\). Let’s construct example two distributions [0, 1] somewhat similar. \(=1,...,500\), let \(X_i \overset{iid}{\sim} F\) \(Y_i\overset{iid}{\sim} F\) F \(\text{Uniform}(0,1)\) \(\text{TruncNormal}(\mu = 0.5, \sigma^2 = 25, = 0, b=1)\). \(\text{TruncNormal}(\mu, \sigma^2, = 0, b=1)\) truncated normal distribution mean \(\mu\), variance \(\sigma^2\), minimum \(\) maximum \(b\). pdf \(\text{TruncNormal}(\mu = 0.5, \sigma^2 = 25, = 0, b=1)\) quite “flat” interval [0, 1]. can look histogram samples see look fairly similar.  can also consider ECDFs see look fairly similar.  Say wish construct equivalence test tolerance value \(\Delta_0 =0.8\), trimming parameter \(\alpha = 0.5\), level \(\alpha^*=0.05\). \[H_0: \Psi_{\alpha, 2}(F, G) \geq 0.8 \quad \text{versus} \quad H_A:  \Psi_{\alpha, 2}(F, G) < 0.8 \] can use mallow_equiv_test function follows: can see output , test p-value 0 less significance level, 0.05, reject \(H_0\) claim \(F\) \(G\) equivalent. Similarly, \(\Delta_0=0.8\) upper \(1-\alpha^* = 0.95\) confidence interval (0, 0.1037). Say instead wish test hypothesis much conservative parameters tolerance value \(\Delta_0 =0.004\) level \(\alpha^*=0.1\) (keep \(\alpha=0.05\)). p-value test 0.5090 fail reject null hypothesis claim equivalence \(F\) \(G\).
code: set.seed(2935) X <- runif(500) Y <- truncnorm::rtruncnorm(500, a = 0, b = 1, mean = 1/2, sd = 5)  par(mfrow = c(1, 2)) hist((X), col = "gray", xlim = c(0,1), main = "Histogram of X's", freq = F) hist((Y), col = "gray", xlim = c(0,1), main = "Histogram of Y's", freq = F) plot(ecdf(X), col = "red") lines(ecdf(Y), col = "blue") test.result <- mallows_equiv_test(X, Y, alpha = 0.05, delta0 = 0.8) test.result #> $dist.hat #> [1] 0.03781523 #>  #> $sd.hat #> [1] 0.9830526 #>  #> $test.stat #> [1] -10.27074 #>  #> $pval #> [1] 4.773456e-25 #>  #> $test.result #> [1] "REJECT NULL" #>  #> $ci #> [1] 0.0000000 0.1036966 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0.05 #>  #> $delta0 #> [1] 0.8 test.result2 <- mallows_equiv_test(X, Y, alpha = 0.05, delta0 = 0.004, sig.level = 0.01) test.result2 #> $dist.hat #> [1] 0.03781523 #>  #> $sd.hat #> [1] 0.9830526 #>  #> $test.stat #> [1] 0.0227426 #>  #> $pval #> [1] 0.5090722 #>  #> $test.result #> [1] "FAIL TO REJECT NULL" #>  #> $ci #> [1] 0.0000000 0.1460677 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0.05 #>  #> $delta0 #> [1] 0.004

Additionally, let \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}} \\mathbb{R}^{d \times d}\) diagonal matrix formed top d largest-magnitude eigenvalues adjacency matrix \(\hat{\boldsymbol{U}} \\mathbb{R}^{n \times d}\) matrix corresponding eigenvectors columns. adjacency spectral embedding \(\boldsymbol{}\) \(\hat{\boldsymbol{X}} = \hat{\boldsymbol{U}}\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{1/2} \\mathbb{R}^{n \times d}\). \(\text{}^{\text{th}}\) row \(\hat{\boldsymbol{X}}\) corresponds location \(\text{}^{\text{th}}\) node d dimensional latent space.

text: Generate bootstrap samples network latent space bootstrap method described Levin Levina (2019) . Latent positions nodes network first calculated \(\mathbb{R}^d\) using adjacency spectral ASE (Sussman et al. 2012) . pair nodes, edge present probability equal dot product positions latent space. Let \(\boldsymbol{}\) adjacency matrix network \(n\) nodes. Additionally, let \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}} \\mathbb{R}^{d \times d}\) diagonal matrix formed top d largest-magnitude eigenvalues adjacency matrix \(\hat{\boldsymbol{U}} \\mathbb{R}^{n \times d}\) matrix corresponding eigenvectors columns. adjacency spectral embedding \(\boldsymbol{}\) \(\hat{\boldsymbol{X}} = \hat{\boldsymbol{U}}\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{1/2} \\mathbb{R}^{n \times d}\). Let \(X_i\) \(\text{}^{\text{th}}\) row \(\hat{\boldsymbol{X}}\), corresponds location \(\text{}^{\text{th}}\) node d dimensional latent space. generate bootstrap adjacency matrix \(\boldsymbol{}^{(b)}\), \(1 \leq < j \leq n\) independently draw \(A_{ij}^{(b)} \sim \text{Bernoulli}(X_i^T X_j)\). may cases \(X_i^T X_j \\[0,1]\). cases, replace \(X_i^T X_j\) \(\max(\min(X_i^T X_j, 1), 0)\).

text: wrapper function generate bootstrap samples network local bootstrap method described Zu Qin (2025) . function uses localboot function generate bootstrap samples, formats fit JaB package syntax. Let \(\boldsymbol{}\) adjacency matrix network \(G \) \(n\) nodes node set \(V\). Let \(\boldsymbol{D}\) distance matrix pairs nodes \(d_{,j}\) distance node \(\) node \(\) according distance function dist.func. Construct neighborhood node \(\mathcal{N}(v_i) = \{v_j \V\ : d_{,j} < d_i^{(s)} \}\) \(d_i^{(s)} \) \(s^{th}\) smallest distance \(d_{,1}, ..., d_{, n}\). construction ensures neighborhood always \(s = |\mathcal(N)(v_i)|\) neighbors. generate bootstrap adjacency matrix \(\boldsymbol{}^{(b)}\), \(1 \leq < j \leq n\) independently draw $$ \begin{align} A_{ij}^{(b)} &\sim \text{Uniform} \Big(\{A_{k\ell} : k \\mathcal{N}(v_{}^{(b)}), \ell \\mathcal{N}(v_{j}^{(b)})\} \Big) \\ v_i^{(b)} &\sim \text{Uniform}(V) \end{align} $$ may cases \(\mathcal{N}(v_{}^{(b)})\) \(\mathcal{N}(v_{j}^{(b)})\) overlapping sets. cases, set  \(\mathcal{N}(v_{}^{(b)}) \cap \mathcal{N}(v_{j}^{(b)}) = \emptyset\).

title: Local Bootstrap — bootstrap_local
text: Zu T, Qin Y (2025). “Local bootstrap network data.” Biometrika, 112(1), asae046.

title: Snowball Sampling (Labeled Snowball with multiple inclusions) — bootstrap_snowboot
text: network igraph object \(n\) nodes. B Number bootstrap samples num.seed Number seeds included snowball sample num.wave Number waves included snowball sample output.type type object resulting bootstrap networks . default igraph make bootstrap samples class "igraph". Note large \(B\), may efficient use storage space. options include edgelist returns edge list bootstrap sample, matrix returns bootstrap samples \(n\)--\(n\) adjacency matrix, dgCMatrix returns sparse matrices (package Matrix must loaded). See make_network_type details.

title: Snowball Sampling (Labeled Snowball with multiple inclusions) — bootstrap_snowboot
text: list length \(B\) element bootstrap sample. element class output.type.

title: Snowball Sampling (Labeled Snowball with multiple inclusions) — bootstrap_snowboot
text: slightly modified version lsmi snowboot package. function inputs igraph object, uses node names (node IDs), returns edge list bootstrap sample (nodes included sample). code function directly lsmi snowboot package. function designed wrapper function format lsmi results JaB package syntax.

title: Snowball Sampling (Labeled Snowball with multiple inclusions) — bootstrap_snowboot
text: Ramirez-Ramirez L, Nezafati K, Chen Y, Lyubchich Y, Gel YR (2022). snowboot: Bootstrap Methods Network Inference. R package version 1.0.2, https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/snowboot. Gel YR, Lyubchich V, Ramirez LR (2017). “Bootstrap quantification estimation uncertainties network degree distributions.” Scientific Reports, 7(1). doi:10.1038/s41598-017-05885-x .

title: Snowball Sampling (Labeled Snowball with multiple inclusions) — bootstrap_snowboot
code: library(igraph) data("karate") # Snowboot Bootstrap set.seed(1) boot.sample <- bootstrap_snowboot(karate, B = 1, num.seed = 1, num.wave = 2)  #plot comparison of original data and bootstrap sample par(mfrow = c(1, 2)) #get the same positions in the original data and bootstrap samples l <- igraph::layout_nicely(karate) which.index <- NA for(i in 1:gorder(boot.sample[[1]])){   which.index[i] <- which(V(boot.sample[[1]])$name[i] == V(karate)$name) }  plot(karate,      layout = l,      main = "Karate Data",      vertex.label = NA) plot(boot.sample[[1]],      layout = l[which.index, ],      main = "Karate Bootstrap Sample",      vertex.label = NA,      vertex.color = V(karate)$Faction[which.index ])

title: Vertex Bootstrap Sampling for networks — bootstrap_vertex

Ramirez-Ramirez L, Nezafati K, Chen Y, Lyubchich Y, Gel YR (2022). snowboot: Bootstrap Methods Network Inference. R package version 1.0.2, https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/snowboot. Snijders TAB, Borgatti SP (1999). “Non-parametric standard errors tests network statistics.” Connections, 22(2), 161--170.

title: Vertex Bootstrap Sampling for networks — bootstrap_vertex
code: library(igraph) data(karate) set.seed(12) boot.samp <- bootstrap_vertex(karate, B=1)  #plot comparison of original data and bootstrap sample par(mfrow = c(1, 2)) #get the same positions in the original data and bootstrap samples l <- igraph::layout_nicely(karate) which.index <- NA for(i in 1:gorder(boot.samp[[1]])){   which.index[i] <- which(V(boot.samp[[1]])$name[i] == V(karate)$name) }  plot(karate,      layout = l,      main = "Karate Data",      vertex.label = NA) plot(boot.samp[[1]],      layout = l[which.index, ],      main = "Karate Bootstrap Sample",      vertex.label = NA,      vertex.color = V(karate)$Faction[which.index ])

what: Detect the Type of Objects in a List — detect_type
title: Detect the Type of Objects in a List — detect_type
text: Attempts detect type network representation list.  Networks can represented "igraph", "dgCMatrix", "edgelist", "matrix".

title: Detect the Type of Objects in a List — detect_type
code: detect_type(obj)

title: Detect the Type of Objects in a List — detect_type
text: obj list networks. networks list must representation. e.g. networks list must edge list.

title: Detect the Type of Objects in a List — detect_type
text: character string indicating representation networks list. Possible return values : "igraph": networks igraph objects. "dgCMatrix": networks sparse matrices class dgCMatrix. "edgelist": networks matrices two columns, representing edge list. "matrix": networks square matrices, typically representing adjacency matrices.

title: Detect the Type of Objects in a List — detect_type
text: function detects input list networks represented "igraph", "dgCMatrix", "edgelist" "matrix". function primarily used internally verifying networks correct format intended operation used. 2--2 matrices default "matrix".

title: Detect the Type of Objects in a List — detect_type
code: # Convert list of adjacency matrices to igraph objects one_matrix <- matrix(c(0, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0), nrow = 3, byrow = TRUE) matrix_list <- replicate(3, one_matrix, simplify = FALSE) igraph_list <-   make_network_type(matrix_list,                    input.type = "matrix",                    output.type = "igraph")  # Same thing now using detect type type <- detect_type(matrix_list) type #> [1] "matrix" igraph_list <-   make_network_type(matrix_list,                    input.type = type,                    output.type = "igraph")  # Convert list of igraph objects to sparse matrix sparsematrix_list <-   make_network_type(igraph_list,                     input.type = "igraph",                     output.type = "dgCMatrix") detect_type(sparsematrix_list) #> [1] "dgCMatrix"

title: Euclidean distance of adjacency spectral embeddings — dist_ASE
text: adjacency matrix \(\boldsymbol{}\) \(n\) nodes, let \(\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}} \\mathbb{R}^{d \times d}\) diagonal matrix formed top d largest-magnitude eigenvalues adjacency matrix \(\hat{\boldsymbol{U}} \\mathbb{R}^{n \times d}\) matrix corresponding eigenvectors columns. adjacency spectral embedding \(\boldsymbol{}\) \(\hat{\boldsymbol{X}} = \hat{\boldsymbol{U}}\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{1/2} \\mathbb{R}^{n \times d}\). , \(D_{,j}\) Euclidean norm \(\hat{\boldsymbol{X}}_{, \cdot}\) \(\hat{\boldsymbol{X}}_{j, \cdot}\).

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression — jab_lm
text: Conduct Jackknife--Bootstrap (JaB) algorithm linear regression (Martin Roberts 2010) .

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression — jab_lm

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression — jab_lm
text: mod lm object. Output stats::lm(). stat character string function name used calculate desired centrality statistic. function must input lm model object first argument output length \(n\) vector statistic interest. quant.lower numeric 0 1 used lower cutoff JaB algorithm. Default 0.05. Must smaller quant.upper. quant.upper numeric 0 1 used upper cutoff JaB algorithm. Default 0.95. Must larger quant.lower. B Number bootstrap samples. Default 3100 package.name character string name package func.name function . left NULL function called loaded users environment. stat.args named list additional arguments func.name function may need beyond mod object.

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression — jab_lm
text: data frame 5 columns. "row.ID": Row Number observation data set used mod. "lower": Lower quantile cutoff determined quant.lower. "upper": Upper quantile cutoff determined quant.upper. "orig": original influence/outlier statistic calculated stat. "influential": Logical flagging observation influential . TRUE orig < lower orig > upper. FALSE otherwise.

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression — jab_lm
text: JaB algorithm, proposed Martin Roberts (2010)  described Beyaztas Alin (2013) , detects influential/outlier points linear regression models. algorithm follows: Let \(\gamma\) (stat) diagnostic statistic interest. Fit model (mod) calculate \(\gamma_i\) \(=1,…,n\). Construct \(B\) bootstrap samples, replacement, original data set. \(= 1,…,n\), 3.1: Let \(B_{()}\) set bootstrap samples contain data point \(\). 3.2: sample \(B_{()}\), fit regression model calculate \(n\) values \(\gamma_{, (b)}\). Aggregate one vector \(\Gamma_i\). 3.1: Calculate suitable quantiles \(\Gamma_i\) (quant.lower quant.upper). \(\gamma_i\) outside range, flag point \(\) influential. default quant.lower quant.upper 0.05 0.95, respectively. means \(\gamma_i\) center 90% \(\Gamma_i\), flagged influential. influence statistics, likelihood distance Cook (1986) , positive values large values imply influence. scenarios, appropriate set quant.lower 0 quant.upper suitable quantile (say 0.90) point \(\) flagged \(\gamma_i\) upper quantiles \(\Gamma_i\). described Martin Roberts (2010) , approximately 1000 bootstrap samples \(B_{()}\), need \(^{1}\approx 3000\) bootstrap samples. See vignette("jab-regression") details examples.

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression — jab_lm
text: Beyaztas U, Alin (2013). “Jackknife--Bootstrap Method Detection Influential Observations Linear Regression Models.” Communications Statistics-Simulation Computation, 42(6), 1256--1267. Cook RD (1986). “Assessment Local Influence.” Journal Royal Statistical Society. Series B (Methodological), 48(2), 133--169. ISSN 00359246, http://www.jstor.org/stable/2345711. Martin MA, Roberts S (2010). “Jackknife--Bootstrap Regression Influence Diagnostics.” Journal Nonparametric Statistics, 22(2), 257-269. doi:10.1080/10485250903287906 .

title: Jackknife-after-Bootstrap for Linear Regression — jab_lm
code: library(stats) data("LifeCycleSavings")  mod <- lm(sr ~ ., data = LifeCycleSavings)  # JaB with DFFITS result1 <- jab_lm(mod,                   stat = "dffits",                   quant.lower = 0.025,                   quant.upper = 0.975,                   B = 3100) result1[result1$influential, ] #>        row.ID      lower     upper       orig influential #> Japan      23 -0.5962788 0.6242944  0.8596508        TRUE #> Zambia     46 -0.6127221 0.6599902  0.7482351        TRUE #> Libya      49 -0.5972119 0.6806704 -1.1601334        TRUE   # define the likelihood distance as influence statistic (Cook, 1986) infl_like <- function(mod){    n <- length(mod$fitted.values)   p <- length(mod$coefficients)    ti <- rstudent(mod)   h <- hatvalues(mod)    p1 <- log( (n/(n-1)) * ((n-p-1) / (ti^2 +n-p-1)) )   p2 <- ti^2 * (n-1) / (1-h) / (n-p-1)    return(n*p1 + p2 - 1) }  # JaB with Likelihood Distance result2 <- jab_lm(mod,                   stat = "infl_like",                   quant.lower = 0.00,                   quant.upper = 0.95,                   B = 3100) #> Error in jab_lm(mod, stat = "infl_like", quant.lower = 0, quant.upper = 0.95,     B = 3100): The functioninfl_likedoes not exist in your environment. result2[result2$influential, ] #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'result2' not found

title: JaB Algorithm for Network Data — jab_network
text: Suppose network \(G\) \(n\) nodes. Specify centrality statistic \(\gamma\). node \(= 1,...,n\) test hypotheses \(H_0\): node \(\) influential network, versus \(H_1\): node \(\) influential network. Define \(q\[0, 1]\) upper quantile cut value \(B\) number bootstrap samples. JaB algorithm three steps: Original Centrality Step: Calculate \(n\) centrality statistics original network, \(\gamma_1, \gamma_2, ..., \gamma_n\). Bootstrapping Step: Generate bootstrap samples \(G^{*b}=(V^{*b}, E^{*b})\) \(b=1,...,B\). bootstrap sample, calculate \(\{\gamma_j^{*b} : j=1,...,n\}\). Jackknife-Step: \(\1,...,n\), : . Calculate \(S_i^{*b} = \boldsymbol{1}(v_i \V^{*b})\) \(b=1,...,B\) construct \(\mathcal{B}_{-} = \{G^{*b}: S_i^{*b} = 0)\) set bootstrap sample networks contain node . B. Let \(\Gamma_{-} = \{\gamma_j^{*b} : G^{*b} \\mathcal{B}_{-}, j=1,...,n\}\) set centrality statistics calculated bootstrap sample networks contain node . C. Calculate cutoff value, \(q_{-}\), \(q^{\text{th}}\) quantile \(\Gamma^{-}\). D. \(\gamma_i > q_{-}\), reject  null hypothesis node \(\) conclude node \(\) influential. run algorithm, set nodes influential set nodes . can also generate ranking nodes least influential determined \(\gamma_i - q_i\) step 3C. Node \(\) considered influential \(\gamma_i - q_i\) large positive, somewhat influential \(\gamma_i - q_i\) small positive, somewhat influential \(\gamma_i - q_i\), influential \(\gamma_i - q_i\) large negative. construct bootstrap standard errors confidence intervals bootstrap samples generated Step 2 algorithm. Let \(\mathcal{B}_i = \{G^{*b} : S_i^{*b} = 1\}\) set bootstrap networks include \(v_i\) \(\Gamma_i = \{\gamma_j : v_j^{*b} = v_i , v_j^{*b} \V^{*b}\}\) set centrality statistics corresponding nodes sampled \(v_i\). bootstrap standard error \(\gamma_i\) \(\sigma_i^{ *} = \sqrt{(|\Gamma_i |-1)^{-1} \sum_{\gamma_j \\Gamma_i} (\gamma_j - \Bar{\gamma}_i)^2}\) \(\Bar{\gamma}_i = |\Gamma_i|^{-1}\sum_{\gamma_j \\Gamma_i} \gamma_j\). Using \(\sigma_i^{ *}\), bootstrap confidence intervals constructed traditional way. example, 95% bootstrap confidence interval \(\gamma_i\) \((\gamma_i - 1.96\sigma_i^{ *} , \gamma_i + 1.96\sigma_i^{ *})\). many centrality statistics \(\gamma_i\) must non-negative value. case \(\gamma_i\) must non-negative  \(\gamma_i - 1.96\sigma_i^{ *}<0\), set 95% bootstrap confidence interval \((0, \gamma_i + 1.96\sigma_i^{ *})\). construction \(\mathcal{B}_i \cap \mathcal{B}_{-} = \emptyset\). bootstrap samples \(\mathcal{B}_i\) used bootstrap standard errors bootstrap samples \(\mathcal{B}_{-}\) used hypothesis test node $v_i$'s influence. Additionally, use sets constructed Step 3(b) JaB algorithm compute p-values. node, associated p-value defined \(p_{-}= |\Gamma_{-}|^{-1}\sum_{\gamma_j \\Gamma_{-}} \boldsymbol{1}(\gamma_j \geq \gamma_i)\), proportion elements \(\Gamma_{-}\) greater equal \(\gamma_i\). Rejecting Null Hypothesis \(\gamma_i > q_{-}\) equivalent rejecting \(p_{-} < q\). jab_network wrapper function entire JaB algorithm. step JaB algorithm, following functions used: Original Centrality Step: Calculate original centrality statistics using get_centrality() according central.func.name. Bootstrapping Step: Generate Bootstrap samples according bootstrap.func.name calculate centrality statistics using get_bootstrap_centrality(). Jackknife-Step: Perform "Jackknife-" step algorithm get_jackknife_after(). See vignette("jab-networks") details examples.

code: # Convert list of adjacency matrices to igraph objects one_matrix <- matrix(c(0, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0), nrow = 3, byrow = TRUE) matrix_list <- replicate(3, one_matrix, simplify = FALSE) igraph_list <-   make_network_type(matrix_list,                    input.type = "matrix",                    output.type = "igraph")  # Same thing now using detect type type <- detect_type(matrix_list) type #> [1] "matrix" igraph_list <-   make_network_type(matrix_list,                    input.type = type,                    output.type = "igraph")  # Convert list of igraph objects to sparse matrix sparsematrix_list <-   make_network_type(igraph_list,                     input.type = "igraph",                     output.type = "dgCMatrix") detect_type(sparsematrix_list) #> [1] "dgCMatrix"

title: Mallows Distance Between Two Vectors — mallows_distance
text: Calculate \(p^{\text{th}}\) Mallows distance two vectors, also known Wasserstein-\(p\) distance two samples size. Say \(X_i \overset{\text{iid}}{\sim} F\) \(Y_j \overset{\text{iid}}{\sim} G\). Let \(\hat{F}(x) = \sum_i\boldsymbol{1}(X_i \leq x)\) \(\hat{F}^{-1}(t) = \text{inf}\{x : \hat{F}(x) \leq t\}\). Define \(\hat{G}(y)\) \(\hat{G}^{-1}(t)\) similarly. \(p^{\text{th}}\) Mallows distance \(\hat{F}(x)\) \(\hat{G}(t)\)  \(\Psi_{p} (\hat{F}, \hat{G}) = \left(\int_{0}^{1} |\hat{F}^{-1}(t) - \hat{G}^{-1}(t) |^p dt \right)^{1/p}\)

title: Mallows Distance Between Two Vectors — mallows_distance
text: Mallows CL (1972). “note asymptotic joint normality.” Annals Mathematical Statistics, 508--515. Munk , Czado C (1998). “Nonparametric validation similar distributions assessment goodness fit.” Journal Royal Statistical Society Series B: Statistical Methodology, 60(1), 223--241.

code: library(igraph) data("karate") set.seed(1) boot.sample <- bootstrap_latent_space(karate, d = 2, B = 1) #> This graph was created by an old(er) igraph version. #>   Call upgrade_graph() on it to use with the current igraph version #>   For now we convert it on the fly...  orig.degree <- get_centrality(karate, "degree") boot.degree <- get_centrality(boot.sample[[1]], "degree")  mallows_distance(orig.degree, boot.degree) #> [1] 1.608799

title: Trimmed Mallows Distance Between Two Vectors — mallows_distance_trimmed
text: Calculate trimmed \(p^{\text{th}}\) Mallows distance two vectors, also known trimmed Wasserstein-\(p\) distance two samples size. Say \(X_i \overset{\text{iid}}{\sim} F\) \(Y_j \overset{\text{iid}}{\sim} G\). Let \(\hat{F}(x) = \sum_i\boldsymbol{1}(X_i \leq x)\) \(\hat{F}^{-1}(t) = \text{inf}\{x : \hat{F}(x) \leq t\}\). Define \(\hat{G}(y)\) \(\hat{G}^{-1}(t)\) similarly. Let \(\alpha\[0,0/5)\) trimming parameter. trimmed \(p^{\text{th}}\) Mallows distance \(\hat{F}(x)\) \(\hat{G}(t)\)  \(\Psi_{\alpha, p}(\hat{F}, \hat{G}) = \left( \frac{1}{1-2\alpha}\int_{\alpha}^{1-\alpha} |\hat{F}^{-1}(t) - \hat{G}^{-1}(t) |^p dt \right)^{1/p}\)

title: Equivalence Test of Two CDFs Using Mallows Distance — mallows_equiv_test
text: list results test: dist.hat estimated trimmed Mallows distance two distributions, \(\Psi_{\alpha, 2}(\hat{F}, \hat{G})\). sd.hat estimate standard deviation two distributions, \(\hat{\sigma}_{\alpha}\). test.stat test statistic. pval p-value test. test.result  "REJECT NULL" pval\(\leq\)sig.level "FAIL REJECT NULL" otherwise. ci upper (1-sig.level) confidence interval square dist.hat alpha trimming parameter used test. Sometimes slightly different input alpha. test requires integer \(\) \(\alpha = /n\). alpha smallest \(\alpha\) makes equation true. See Munk Czado (1998)  details. delta0 tolerance parameter used test. input delta0.

title: Equivalence Test of Two CDFs Using Mallows Distance — mallows_equiv_test
text: equivalence test two CDFs using trimmed Mallows distance proposed Munk Czado (1998) . Say \(X_i \overset{iid}{\sim} F\) \(Y_j \overset{iid}{\sim} G\) \(,j = 1, ..., n\) \(F\) \(G\) continuous distribution functions. Let \(\hat{F}_n(x) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^n \boldsymbol{1}\{X_i \leq x\}\) denote empirical cumulative distribution function (ECDF) \(X\), \(\hat{F}^{-1}_n(t) = \inf\{x : F_n(x) \geq t\}\) denote quantile function. Define \(\hat{G}_m(y)\) \(\hat{G}^{-1}_m(t)\) similarly \(Y\). Trimmed \(p^{th}\) Mallows distance trimming parameter \(\alpha \[0, 1/2)\) : \(\begin{equation} \Psi_{\alpha, p}(F, G) =  \frac{1}{1-2\alpha} \left[ \int_{\alpha}^{1-\alpha} | F^{-1}(u) - G^{-1}(u) | ^p du \right]^{1/p}. \end{equation} \) Munk Czado (1998)  conduct equivalence test suitable \(0<\Delta_0\\mathbb{R}\): \( \begin{equation} H_0: \Psi_{\alpha, 2}(F, G) \geq \Delta_0 \quad \text{versus} \quad H_A:  \Psi_{\alpha, 2}(F, G) < \Delta_0 \end{equation} \) , consistent level \(\alpha^*\) test hypothesis rejects \(H_0\) , \( \begin{equation}\label{eqn:MallowTest} \left(\frac{nm}{n+m}\right)^{1/2} \frac{\Psi^2_{\alpha_{n \wedge m}, 2}(\hat{F}_n, \hat{G}_n) - \Delta_0^2}{\hat{\sigma}_{\alpha}(F, G)} \leq q_{\alpha^*} \end{equation} \) \(q_{\alpha^*}\) \(\alpha^*\) quantile standard normal distribution \(\hat{\sigma}_{\alpha}\) consistent estimator expected variance \(F\) \(G\). See vignette("mallows-equiv-test") Appendix Munk Czado (1998)  explicit expression \(\hat{\sigma}_{\alpha}\). Currently, function runs \(n=m\). theory still holds \(n\neq m\). See vignette("mallows-equiv-test") details construction test.

title: Equivalence Test of Two CDFs Using Mallows Distance — mallows_equiv_test
code: set.seed(2935) X <- runif(500) Y <- truncnorm::rtruncnorm(500, a = 0, b = 1, mean = 1/2, sd = 5)  # Plot the ECDFs plot(ecdf(X), col = "red") lines(ecdf(Y), col = "blue")   # Run the test for trimming parameter 0.05, tolerance value of 0.8 and # significance level of 0.05. test.result <- mallows_equiv_test(X, Y, alpha = 0.05, delta0 = 0.8) test.result #> $dist.hat #> [1] 0.03781523 #>  #> $sd.hat #> [1] 0.9830526 #>  #> $test.stat #> [1] -10.27074 #>  #> $pval #> [1] 4.773456e-25 #>  #> $test.result #> [1] "REJECT NULL" #>  #> $ci #> [1] 0.0000000 0.1036966 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0.05 #>  #> $delta0 #> [1] 0.8 #>
